# Is it even possible to open a link in a Google doc without multiple clicks?

My company uses Google docs. Most of the time, there are many links to _other_Â Google docs in any given document.

I often need to open many such links at a time. Say you want to open 6 links (which is typical), you have to either:

**Using Mouse**

1\. Click the Doc link

2\. Wait for the "preview" to appear

3\. Click the _actual_ link in the preview

4\. Navigate _back_Â to the original doc, because the link took focus in the browser.

^ repeat for every link you need to open

**Using Hotkeys**

1\. Position your cursor over the link you want

2\. Hit "Option+Enter"

3\. NavigateÂ _back_Â to the original doc, because the link took focus in the browser.

^ repeat for every link you need to open

Is there _any way_ to streamline this? On Google search, you can Command+click or Ctrl+click dozens of links to open them in background tabs. It's easy. Is there an easy way to do this in Google docs? Why is there so much friction?

You can submit your concerns by opening a Docs document and going toÂ **Help > Help Docs improve**. _The team is unable to respond to individual users_, but they do reviewÂ all feedback sent to them and useÂ it to improve the product over time.

Content:
[0](https://learninginhand.com/cart)

# Google Document URL Tricks

Aug 17, 2017

Written By [Tony Vincent](https://learninginhand.com/blog?author=50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12db)

![Google Document URL Tricks](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729521122-QM9SFIWH2V6OZBJKKZWA/URL+Tricks+Updated+Title+Design.001.png)

Google Workspace includes Google **Documents**, **Sheets**, **Slides**, and **Drawings**. These apps can provide shareable links. Shareable links can be used for publishing a document or for collaboratively editing a document.

![Google Docs, Google Sheets, Google Slides, Google Drawgings](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502978604818-H0L2QNSMH9TUAGIJB9RS/image-asset.png)

Documents are only accessible by you (the owner) unless you **turn link sharing on**. One way to turn on link sharing is by clicking the _Share_ button in an open document. Then you'll see an option to _Get shareable link_. Clicking that option turns link sharing on and copies the link to your clipboard. The link is set to _Anyone with the link can_ **_view_** _._ You can change this to _Anyone with the link can_ **_comment_** or **_edit._**

![Get Shareable LInk](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502978919523-F0YTEON9CTEDYWJFLVTS/image-asset.png)

Once you have the shareable link copied, you can paste it into a document, webpage, link shortener, Twitter, Facebook, etc. By replacing _/edit_Â in the URL, you can do some pretty nifty tricks. You can transform a shareable link into a **Preview**, **Copy**, **Template**, or **PDF** link.

Below are glanceable graphics for each kind of link. Scroll down for detailed descriptions and tips.

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729314040-7L0N45OT13VHB8GTD3N2/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.002.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729314168-9ALNG7NPEJFKZH20EQVV/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.003.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729313104-LWEWOEH2RX3V0QC93BMW/Make+a+Copy+with+Comments+Updated+Design.001.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729313163-GULT5G5NG0P7JHKX9LEP/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.001.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729315179-PRVVG5TAGTFQV4MQX8MB/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.005.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729315073-85DXEWXLP5NQQ16GOC5Q/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.004.png)

![Preview Link Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982794023-80BGBK7DVXSMAXIL2T9I/image-asset.png)

## Preview Link

**_Share a clutter-free view of your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/preview_

Publishing whatâ€™s created in Google Docs, Sheets, Slides, or Drawings as a Preview link presents the document without menu bars and buttons. A Preview link declutters the web page, which emphases your content over the tool you used to create it. In fact, your audience may not know you created the document in Google Workspace.

Preview links are good for newsletters, flyers, and instructional materials. It's also great for when you want to present a Google Slides presentation full screen. A preview link shows slides in presentation view, and it keeps your browser tabs visible (making it easy to switch between the presentation and other webpages).

Example: [Classy Graphics Manifesto](https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1sVZYYazblxw5lhO8ZlblHSe42y0ZhJpb1kTK-vYT9eM/preview)

- Previewed documents load faster and work much better in mobile browsers than the standard shareable version. This is particularly true with Google Drawings, which does not have a mobile app.

- Comments and anything that is off the slide or canvas is not displayed in a previewed document. Furthermore, a Slides presentation does not have the slide sorterâ€”the presentation is shown in Presentation view.

- The audience for a Preview link does not see editing in real-time. However, a recent version of the document is shown each time the page is loaded. Thereâ€™s no need to republish or reshare the document to update the Preview version. Note that the preview might take several minutes to update.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /preview. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- Changing _/edit_ to _/preview?rm=minimal_ in Google Slides presents the slideshow without the navigation bar at the bottom. This is handy when you do not want your audience to skip slides. (Thanks to Shaun Creighton in the comments for this tip!)

- Since a Preview link removes menus, viewers of your document will not have the ability to choose File â†’ Make a Copy to add a copy to their own Google Drive. However, if you encounter a Preview version of a document and wish to make a copy, try this: Replace /preview with /edit in the URL. Youâ€™ll then see the version with menus and you can then access the File menu to make a copy.

- A Preview link for a Google Doc does not show the document outline (the list of headings on the left side). But, you can modify the URL to be a Preview link _and_ show the document outline. Simple replace /edit with /preview?rm=demo. Thanks to [Wanda Terral](https://ignitionedu.com/2024/06/google-doc-demo-mode) for this tip.

- Adding a Preview URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Preview version. If you want to add a Preview link, first paste the Preview link into URL shortener like [Bitly](http://bitly.com/). Copy the new link Bitly provides. Adding the shortened link to a post in Google Classroom will end up opening the Preview version. Alternatively, you could paste the Preview link into the body of the post (instead of using the link button to add the link).


View fullsize

![Preview Link graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729591884-8CYC53HWZHD6LORALIW9/Preview.png)

![Make a Copy Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982823815-SMLPS8IQZAMUVXG3S0K4/image-asset.png)

## Make a Copy Link

**_Force others to make a copy before viewing your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/copy_

Youâ€™ve probably clicked a link to a Google Docs, Slides, Sheets, or Drawings file and had to click a Make a Copy button before proceeding. This method of sharing forces a user to make a copy of the original, and the copy is now fully owned by the user and placed in her Google Drive.

Make a Copy links are good for when you have created a document in Google Workspace and want students to have their very own copy. Students can fill in blanks, finish a slideshow, label a drawing, annotate text, or complete some task in their own document (and then possibly share it back with the teacher). Sharing this way is also useful for sharing templates with other teachers. They can simply click to make their own copy and customize it without affecting your original.

Example: [Notes of Encouragement (for printing on 1.5 x 2 inch sticky notes)](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1qf_TVpBxkVgBdp-X22x99u8_WYM3x8axrzX1Hi1ewbM/copy?usp=sharing)

- Google Classroom automates this process when teachers post assignments that include a Google document. Classroom gives the option to make a copy for each student.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /copy. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- Comments will not be copied over when you change /edit to /copy. If you want to include comments, see _Make a Copy with Comments Link_ below **.**

- When students and teachers make a copy, they have full ownership of the copy and the original document owner is no longer associated with the copy. If the first document owner makes changes to the original document, those changes be reflected in future copies, but will not change copies already made of the document.


View fullsize

![Make a Copy LInk Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729627244-8KB2EA181CKVCBCSUGHD/Make+a+Copy.png)

![Copy with Comments Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1523975766724-6PTJ7TBUAY02YRTFED1E/Copy+with+Comments.png)

## Make a Copy with Comments Link

**_Force others to make a copy that includes comments from the original before viewing your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/copy?copyComments=true_

This link works just like the regular _Make a Copy_Â link, but it also copies any comments from the original document into the copy. This can be handy if there are comments you want viewers to see and possibly reply to. Comments may include additional information, instructions, checklists, and hyperlinks.

Example: [Lines of Symmetry by Eric Curts](https://docs.google.com/document/d/18ox23HzI4g0C0aJgi6ITLwpWD46Rd5ofvkWH2DJLzCA/copy?copyComments=true)

- Comments that are copied from the original document include the notice, "Comments above copied from original document."

- For more information about this kind of link, read Eric Curt's post [How to Force a Docs Copy WITH Pre-Loaded Comments to Help your Students.](http://www.controlaltachieve.com/2017/11/force-copy-comments.html)

- If you highlight text or select an image before clicking the Comment button, the comment will be associated with that selection.

- Adding a Make a Copy with Comments URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Copy with Comments version. If you want to add a Copy with Comments link, first paste the link into URL shortener like [Bitly](http://bitly.com/). Copy the new link Bitly provides. Adding the shortened link to a post in Google Classroom will end up opening the Make a Copy with Comments version. Alternatively, you could paste the Make a Copy with Comments link into the body of the post (instead of using the link button to add the link).


![Make a Copy with Comments](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729650175-X21L5WIV33MBLF0K25NS/Make+a+Copy+with+Comments.png)

![Template Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982857432-LWHNLOR2IIULLV4N0T0A/image-asset.png)

## Template Link

**_Share an easy-to-copy preview of your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/template/preview_

Use a Template link to share the contents of your document with the option to make a copyâ€”it's a combination of a Preview link and a Make a Copy link.

A Template link presents a clutter-free version of your document. It also displays a _Use Template_ button. Clicking this button makes a copy of the original document, and the copy is now fully owned by the user and placed in her Google Drive.

Template links are good for allowing others to see the document before copying to Google Drive. These kinds of links are usually preferred over Make a Copy links when posting on websites and social media since they allow the document to be seen before blindly being copied.

Example: [Magnetic Poetry](https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1VceC_EgHOvzJ-mxMCJW1e7d9ipEFB3qF9sAvuoGTJJg/template/preview)

- Unlike clicking the _Make a Copy_ button, clicking _Use Template_ does not put "Copy of" in the newly copied document's file name.

- The audience for a Template link does not see editing in real-time. However, a recent version of the document is shown each time the page is loaded. Thereâ€™s no need to republish or reshare the document to update the Template version. Note that the document's preview might take several minutes to update.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /copy. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- iPhones and iPads are a little quirky when it comes to Template links. After clicking _Use Template_, the freshly copied document does not automatically open in the Documents, Sheets, or Slides app. However, when the app is opened, the new document is there. Sorting by _Last modified_ can make finding the document easier.

- Adding a Template URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Template version. If you want to add a Template link, first paste the Template link into URL shortener like [Bitly](http://bitly.com/). Copy the new link Bitly provides. Adding the shortened link to a post in Google Classroom will end up opening the Template version. Alternatively, you could paste the Template link into the body of the post (instead of using the link button to add the link).


View fullsize

![Template Link Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729687412-OBC4I1CFXPCS6BCFU2QU/Template.png)

![PDF icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982880518-UUSE0BQBGTWVY9FST2C9/image-asset.png)

## PDF Link

**_Share a direct download of a PDF version of your document_**

â†’ Google Docs & Sheets: Replace _/edit_Â with _/export?format=pdf_

â†’ Google Slides & Drawings: Replace _/edit_Â with _/export/pdf_

Have the web browser download a PDF version of your document with a PDF link. Instead of displaying the document in Google's viewer or app, a PDF is automatically downloaded when the link is clicked.

PDF links are good for when you want others to print or save your document. They are handy for sharing posters,Â infographics and cheat sheets.

Example: [Google Classroom Post Options](https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1fvtnOG9iJRjtyKHxKeD2alssU635mhGHYqwzYITszys/export/pdf)

- Since a PDF is a universal format, a Google account is not required to download and not necessary to open the file.

- PDF files may open in any number of apps: Adobe Reader, Preview, Google Drive, Foxit Reader, Explain Everything, etc.

- Automatic downloads do not appear in the browser window on computers. It is easy for someone to miss that a file was downloaded when clicked. Be sure to label your PDF link so that others know that a file will be downloaded.

- Downloads go to different places, depending on the browser, computer, and settings. The recipient might be prompted to rename the file and choose a location. Or, a downloaded file might automatically be placed in a Downloads folder or on the desktop.

- Hyperlinks do work in PDFs. Any text, images, or shapes that you have hyperlinked in your document will remain linked in the PDF version.

- Direct downloads are not limited to PDF. Other file types also work. Instead of using _pdf_ in URL, try _png, jpg, pptx, xlsx, docx, html,_ or _txt_.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /copy. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- If you'd like the PDF to display in the browser, you can use Google's online document viewer. Add _https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=_ to the beginning of the PDF link. [Click to see an example.](https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1fvtnOG9iJRjtyKHxKeD2alssU635mhGHYqwzYITszys/export/pdf)


View fullsize

![PDF LInk for Docs and Sheets Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729706901-LU0JFXIL44CEFB04FDQT/image-asset.png)

View fullsize

![PDF LInk for Slides and Drawings Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729716414-1ZPJ9MS7FMXMTYG5APE9/PDF+Slides+Drawings.png)

* * *

![Reverse](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502983319038-8O4BO5EBY4XT64MTISIT/image-asset.png)

### **Bonus Tip**

Come across someone else's tricked out link? You can reverse engineer a Preview, Make a Copy, Template, or PDF link to see the document in the regular way by replacing _/preview, /copy, /template/preview, /export?format=pdf, or /export/pdf_ with _/edit_.

* * *

### Bonus Bonus Tip

The [Sir Links-a-Lot extension for Google Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/sir-links-a-lot/cggpkbnlnicoanmphgkkcmidbpdacepn?hl=en-US) will generate a preview, copy, template, or PDF URL for a document you have open. You then click a button to copy the generated link. You do need to manually set the document's sharing setting so that anyone can view.

[![Sir Links-a-lot Extension Panel](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1521668429658-SKAU4376PZ2NE7RVS3J5/Screen+Shot+2018-03-21+at+4.39.45+PM.png)](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/sir-links-a-lot/cggpkbnlnicoanmphgkkcmidbpdacepn/related?hl=en-US)

Tony Vincent5 years agoPendingAwaiting Moderation

Hi Liz! If you set the Share setting so that anyone is a Viewer, even if they reverse the /preview link to /edit, they cannot actually edit the document.

Instead of sharing so that anyone with the link is a Viewer, you could Share with specific emails (paste your student and parent email addresses) and make them Viewers (not Editors). You don't need to notify them. Then when you include the link in the body of a Google Classroom post, they will see the Preview version and can click links. Only the people logged into the emails you pasterd into Share will be able to see it.

Hey Tony! Thanks for always providing such helpful info! When you have a minute, could you please explain a couple things?

1. What's the difference between posting something as preview/present vs. publishing it to the web? Is the view the same for each?
2. Are there specific instances when one is better to use than the other?

Thank you so much! :-)

Preview
Post Reply


![](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v2/namespaces/memberAccountAvatars/libraries/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12db/25dedc04d3c341d4929edc1b27b15aec/25dedc04d3c341d4929edc1b27b15aec.jpeg?format=300w?&format=100w)

Tony Vincent5 years agoPendingAwaiting Moderation

Hi Tara!

Changing to /preview and publishing to the web are very similar. Both open the presentation so that it takes up the entire browser tab.

Changing to /preview requires that you have shared the document so that anyone with the link can view. It's possible for someone to change the /preview to /edit and then make a copy of the slides. The toolbar is always showing along the bottom of the window.

Publishing to the web shares the presentation in a way that doesn't allow copying. Publishing to the web gives you embed code for putting onto webpages. Publishing also gives you the option to auto-advance the slides and loop the presentation. The toolbar floats near the bottom and disappears after a few seconds.

Adding a Preview URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Preview version. If you want to add a Preview link, first paste the Preview link into URL shortener like Bitly. Copy the new link Bitly provides. Adding the shortened link to a post in Google Classroom will end up opening the Preview version. Alternatively, you could paste the Preview link into the body of the post (instead of using the link button to add the link).

Yes, you can share a Google Drive file without revealing your email address by using a few different methods:

1. Shareable Link:

    \- You can create a shareable link for your file.

    \- Right-click on the file in Google Drive, select "Get link," and then change the link settings to "Anyone with the link."

    \- You can then share this link without disclosing your email address.
2. Anonymous Access:

    \- If you use the shareable link method, users with the link can access the file without needing to log in or provide an email address, depending on the permissions you set.
3. Using a Different Account:

    \- If you want to keep your email completely private, you can create a new Google account specifically for sharing files. You can then share files from this account.
4. Third-party Services:

    \- Some third-party file-sharing services allow you to upload files and share them without revealing your email. However, be cautious with sensitive information when using third-party services.

Make sure to review the access settings to control who can view, comment, or edit the file.

# Is it even possible to open a link in a Google doc without multiple clicks?

My company uses Google docs. Most of the time, there are many links to _other_Â Google docs in any given document.

I often need to open many such links at a time. Say you want to open 6 links (which is typical), you have to either:

**Using Mouse**

1\. Click the Doc link

2\. Wait for the "preview" to appear

3\. Click the _actual_ link in the preview

4\. Navigate _back_Â to the original doc, because the link took focus in the browser.

^ repeat for every link you need to open

**Using Hotkeys**

1\. Position your cursor over the link you want

2\. Hit "Option+Enter"

3\. NavigateÂ _back_Â to the original doc, because the link took focus in the browser.

^ repeat for every link you need to open

Is there _any way_ to streamline this? On Google search, you can Command+click or Ctrl+click dozens of links to open them in background tabs. It's easy. Is there an easy way to do this in Google docs? Why is there so much friction?

# Google Document URL Tricks

Aug 17, 2017

Written By [Tony Vincent](https://learninginhand.com/blog?author=50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12db)

![Google Document URL Tricks](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729521122-QM9SFIWH2V6OZBJKKZWA/URL+Tricks+Updated+Title+Design.001.png)

Google Workspace includes Google **Documents**, **Sheets**, **Slides**, and **Drawings**. These apps can provide shareable links. Shareable links can be used for publishing a document or for collaboratively editing a document.

![Google Docs, Google Sheets, Google Slides, Google Drawgings](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502978604818-H0L2QNSMH9TUAGIJB9RS/image-asset.png)

Documents are only accessible by you (the owner) unless you **turn link sharing on**. One way to turn on link sharing is by clicking the _Share_ button in an open document. Then you'll see an option to _Get shareable link_. Clicking that option turns link sharing on and copies the link to your clipboard. The link is set to _Anyone with the link can_ **_view_** _._ You can change this to _Anyone with the link can_ **_comment_** or **_edit._**

![Get Shareable LInk](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502978919523-F0YTEON9CTEDYWJFLVTS/image-asset.png)

Once you have the shareable link copied, you can paste it into a document, webpage, link shortener, Twitter, Facebook, etc. By replacing _/edit_Â in the URL, you can do some pretty nifty tricks. You can transform a shareable link into a **Preview**, **Copy**, **Template**, or **PDF** link.

Below are glanceable graphics for each kind of link. Scroll down for detailed descriptions and tips.

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729314040-7L0N45OT13VHB8GTD3N2/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.002.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729314168-9ALNG7NPEJFKZH20EQVV/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.003.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729313104-LWEWOEH2RX3V0QC93BMW/Make+a+Copy+with+Comments+Updated+Design.001.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729313163-GULT5G5NG0P7JHKX9LEP/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.001.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729315179-PRVVG5TAGTFQV4MQX8MB/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.005.png)

[View fullsize](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729315073-85DXEWXLP5NQQ16GOC5Q/URL+Tricks+Updated+Dresigns.004.png)

![Preview Link Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982794023-80BGBK7DVXSMAXIL2T9I/image-asset.png)

## Preview Link

**_Share a clutter-free view of your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/preview_

Publishing whatâ€™s created in Google Docs, Sheets, Slides, or Drawings as a Preview link presents the document without menu bars and buttons. A Preview link declutters the web page, which emphases your content over the tool you used to create it. In fact, your audience may not know you created the document in Google Workspace.

Preview links are good for newsletters, flyers, and instructional materials. It's also great for when you want to present a Google Slides presentation full screen. A preview link shows slides in presentation view, and it keeps your browser tabs visible (making it easy to switch between the presentation and other webpages).

Example: [Classy Graphics Manifesto](https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1sVZYYazblxw5lhO8ZlblHSe42y0ZhJpb1kTK-vYT9eM/preview)

- Previewed documents load faster and work much better in mobile browsers than the standard shareable version. This is particularly true with Google Drawings, which does not have a mobile app.

- Comments and anything that is off the slide or canvas is not displayed in a previewed document. Furthermore, a Slides presentation does not have the slide sorterâ€”the presentation is shown in Presentation view.

- The audience for a Preview link does not see editing in real-time. However, a recent version of the document is shown each time the page is loaded. Thereâ€™s no need to republish or reshare the document to update the Preview version. Note that the preview might take several minutes to update.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /preview. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- Changing _/edit_ to _/preview?rm=minimal_ in Google Slides presents the slideshow without the navigation bar at the bottom. This is handy when you do not want your audience to skip slides. (Thanks to Shaun Creighton in the comments for this tip!)

- Since a Preview link removes menus, viewers of your document will not have the ability to choose File â†’ Make a Copy to add a copy to their own Google Drive. However, if you encounter a Preview version of a document and wish to make a copy, try this: Replace /preview with /edit in the URL. Youâ€™ll then see the version with menus and you can then access the File menu to make a copy.

- A Preview link for a Google Doc does not show the document outline (the list of headings on the left side). But, you can modify the URL to be a Preview link _and_ show the document outline. Simple replace /edit with /preview?rm=demo. Thanks to [Wanda Terral](https://ignitionedu.com/2024/06/google-doc-demo-mode) for this tip.

- Adding a Preview URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Preview version. If you want to add a Preview link, first paste the Preview link into URL shortener like [Bitly](http://bitly.com/). Copy the new link Bitly provides. Adding the shortened link to a post in Google Classroom will end up opening the Preview version. Alternatively, you could paste the Preview link into the body of the post (instead of using the link button to add the link).


View fullsize

![Preview Link graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729591884-8CYC53HWZHD6LORALIW9/Preview.png)

![Make a Copy Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982823815-SMLPS8IQZAMUVXG3S0K4/image-asset.png)

## Make a Copy Link

**_Force others to make a copy before viewing your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/copy_

Youâ€™ve probably clicked a link to a Google Docs, Slides, Sheets, or Drawings file and had to click a Make a Copy button before proceeding. This method of sharing forces a user to make a copy of the original, and the copy is now fully owned by the user and placed in her Google Drive.

Make a Copy links are good for when you have created a document in Google Workspace and want students to have their very own copy. Students can fill in blanks, finish a slideshow, label a drawing, annotate text, or complete some task in their own document (and then possibly share it back with the teacher). Sharing this way is also useful for sharing templates with other teachers. They can simply click to make their own copy and customize it without affecting your original.

Example: [Notes of Encouragement (for printing on 1.5 x 2 inch sticky notes)](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1qf_TVpBxkVgBdp-X22x99u8_WYM3x8axrzX1Hi1ewbM/copy?usp=sharing)

- Google Classroom automates this process when teachers post assignments that include a Google document. Classroom gives the option to make a copy for each student.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /copy. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- Comments will not be copied over when you change /edit to /copy. If you want to include comments, see _Make a Copy with Comments Link_ below **.**

- When students and teachers make a copy, they have full ownership of the copy and the original document owner is no longer associated with the copy. If the first document owner makes changes to the original document, those changes be reflected in future copies, but will not change copies already made of the document.


View fullsize

![Make a Copy LInk Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729627244-8KB2EA181CKVCBCSUGHD/Make+a+Copy.png)

![Copy with Comments Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1523975766724-6PTJ7TBUAY02YRTFED1E/Copy+with+Comments.png)

## Make a Copy with Comments Link

**_Force others to make a copy that includes comments from the original before viewing your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/copy?copyComments=true_

This link works just like the regular _Make a Copy_Â link, but it also copies any comments from the original document into the copy. This can be handy if there are comments you want viewers to see and possibly reply to. Comments may include additional information, instructions, checklists, and hyperlinks.

Example: [Lines of Symmetry by Eric Curts](https://docs.google.com/document/d/18ox23HzI4g0C0aJgi6ITLwpWD46Rd5ofvkWH2DJLzCA/copy?copyComments=true)

- Comments that are copied from the original document include the notice, "Comments above copied from original document."

- For more information about this kind of link, read Eric Curt's post [How to Force a Docs Copy WITH Pre-Loaded Comments to Help your Students.](http://www.controlaltachieve.com/2017/11/force-copy-comments.html)

- If you highlight text or select an image before clicking the Comment button, the comment will be associated with that selection.

- Adding a Make a Copy with Comments URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Copy with Comments version. If you want to add a Copy with Comments link, first paste the link into URL shortener like [Bitly](http://bitly.com/). Copy the new link Bitly provides. Adding the shortened link to a post in Google Classroom will end up opening the Make a Copy with Comments version. Alternatively, you could paste the Make a Copy with Comments link into the body of the post (instead of using the link button to add the link).


![Make a Copy with Comments](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729650175-X21L5WIV33MBLF0K25NS/Make+a+Copy+with+Comments.png)

![Template Icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982857432-LWHNLOR2IIULLV4N0T0A/image-asset.png)

## Template Link

**_Share an easy-to-copy preview of your document_**

â†’ Replace _/edit_Â with _/template/preview_

Use a Template link to share the contents of your document with the option to make a copyâ€”it's a combination of a Preview link and a Make a Copy link.

A Template link presents a clutter-free version of your document. It also displays a _Use Template_ button. Clicking this button makes a copy of the original document, and the copy is now fully owned by the user and placed in her Google Drive.

Template links are good for allowing others to see the document before copying to Google Drive. These kinds of links are usually preferred over Make a Copy links when posting on websites and social media since they allow the document to be seen before blindly being copied.

Example: [Magnetic Poetry](https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1VceC_EgHOvzJ-mxMCJW1e7d9ipEFB3qF9sAvuoGTJJg/template/preview)

- Unlike clicking the _Make a Copy_ button, clicking _Use Template_ does not put "Copy of" in the newly copied document's file name.

- The audience for a Template link does not see editing in real-time. However, a recent version of the document is shown each time the page is loaded. Thereâ€™s no need to republish or reshare the document to update the Template version. Note that the document's preview might take several minutes to update.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /copy. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- iPhones and iPads are a little quirky when it comes to Template links. After clicking _Use Template_, the freshly copied document does not automatically open in the Documents, Sheets, or Slides app. However, when the app is opened, the new document is there. Sorting by _Last modified_ can make finding the document easier.

- Adding a Template URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Template version. If you want to add a Template link, first paste the Template link into URL shortener like [Bitly](http://bitly.com/). Copy the new link Bitly provides. Adding the shortened link to a post in Google Classroom will end up opening the Template version. Alternatively, you could paste the Template link into the body of the post (instead of using the link button to add the link).


View fullsize

![Template Link Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729687412-OBC4I1CFXPCS6BCFU2QU/Template.png)

![PDF icon](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1502982880518-UUSE0BQBGTWVY9FST2C9/image-asset.png)

## PDF Link

**_Share a direct download of a PDF version of your document_**

â†’ Google Docs & Sheets: Replace _/edit_Â with _/export?format=pdf_

â†’ Google Slides & Drawings: Replace _/edit_Â with _/export/pdf_

Have the web browser download a PDF version of your document with a PDF link. Instead of displaying the document in Google's viewer or app, a PDF is automatically downloaded when the link is clicked.

PDF links are good for when you want others to print or save your document. They are handy for sharing posters,Â infographics and cheat sheets.

Example: [Google Classroom Post Options](https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1fvtnOG9iJRjtyKHxKeD2alssU635mhGHYqwzYITszys/export/pdf)

- Since a PDF is a universal format, a Google account is not required to download and not necessary to open the file.

- PDF files may open in any number of apps: Adobe Reader, Preview, Google Drive, Foxit Reader, Explain Everything, etc.

- Automatic downloads do not appear in the browser window on computers. It is easy for someone to miss that a file was downloaded when clicked. Be sure to label your PDF link so that others know that a file will be downloaded.

- Downloads go to different places, depending on the browser, computer, and settings. The recipient might be prompted to rename the file and choose a location. Or, a downloaded file might automatically be placed in a Downloads folder or on the desktop.

- Hyperlinks do work in PDFs. Any text, images, or shapes that you have hyperlinked in your document will remain linked in the PDF version.

- Direct downloads are not limited to PDF. Other file types also work. Instead of using _pdf_ in URL, try _png, jpg, pptx, xlsx, docx, html,_ or _txt_.

- Your shareable link from Google documents might have some additional characters after /edit. Donâ€™t worry about them. Simply replace /edit with /copy. You can either keep or delete what was after /edit and your link should work just fine.

- If you'd like the PDF to display in the browser, you can use Google's online document viewer. Add _https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=_ to the beginning of the PDF link. [Click to see an example.](https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1fvtnOG9iJRjtyKHxKeD2alssU635mhGHYqwzYITszys/export/pdf)


View fullsize

![PDF LInk for Docs and Sheets Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729706901-LU0JFXIL44CEFB04FDQT/image-asset.png)

View fullsize

![PDF LInk for Slides and Drawings Graphic by Tony Vincent](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v1/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12d9/1561729716414-1ZPJ9MS7FMXMTYG5APE9/PDF+Slides+Drawings.png)

### **Bonus Tip**

Come across someone else's tricked out link? You can reverse engineer a Preview, Make a Copy, Template, or PDF link to see the document in the regular way by replacing _/preview, /copy, /template/preview, /export?format=pdf, or /export/pdf_ with _/edit_.

* * *

The [Sir Links-a-Lot extension for Google Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/sir-links-a-lot/cggpkbnlnicoanmphgkkcmidbpdacepn?hl=en-US) will generate a preview, copy, template, or PDF URL for a document you have open. You then click a button to copy the generated link. You do need to manually set the document's sharing setting so that anyone can view.

Tony Vincent5 years agoPendingAwaiting Moderation

Hi Liz! If you set the Share setting so that anyone is a Viewer, even if they reverse the /preview link to /edit, they cannot actually edit the document.

Instead of sharing so that anyone with the link is a Viewer, you could Share with specific emails (paste your student and parent email addresses) and make them Viewers (not Editors). You don't need to notify them. Then when you include the link in the body of a Google Classroom post, they will see the Preview version and can click links. Only the people logged into the emails you pasterd into Share will be able to see it.

Hey Tony! Thanks for always providing such helpful info! When you have a minute, could you please explain a couple things?

1. What's the difference between posting something as preview/present vs. publishing it to the web? Is the view the same for each?
2. Are there specific instances when one is better to use than the other?

Thank you so much! :-)

Preview
Post Reply


![](https://images.squarespace-cdn.com/content/v2/namespaces/memberAccountAvatars/libraries/50eca855e4b0939ae8bb12db/25dedc04d3c341d4929edc1b27b15aec/25dedc04d3c341d4929edc1b27b15aec.jpeg?format=300w?&format=100w)

Tony Vincent5 years agoPendingAwaiting Moderation

Hi Tara!

Changing to /preview and publishing to the web are very similar. Both open the presentation so that it takes up the entire browser tab.

Changing to /preview requires that you have shared the document so that anyone with the link can view. It's possible for someone to change the /preview to /edit and then make a copy of the slides. The toolbar is always showing along the bottom of the window.

Publishing to the web shares the presentation in a way that doesn't allow copying. Publishing to the web gives you embed code for putting onto webpages. Publishing also gives you the option to auto-advance the slides and loop the presentation. The toolbar floats near the bottom and disappears after a few seconds.

2\. Select the slides you want to make into PNGÂ´s (in this case all of them.

3\. In the File menu, select export.

4\. When prompted, select the type of file you want the slides to be exported to be, ex: PNG, and confirm.

5\. All the slides will download as PNGÂ´s files (or any other format selected from the options given).

I do this all the time to create backgrounds for our slides decks os virtual manipulative. Game changer to make sure the kiddos wonÂ´t be able to edit anything else beyond what comprises the actual task on hand.

BTW, Jamboard (FINALLY!) allows to add backgrounds, too!

Adding a Preview URL for a document to a Google Classroom post ends up reverting to the original version, not the Preview version. If you want to add a Preview link, first paste the Preview link into URL shortener like Bitly. Copy the new link Bitly provides. Yes, you can share a Google Drive file without revealing your email address by using a few different methods:

1. Shareable Link:

    \- You can create a shareable link for your file.

    \- Right-click on the file in Google Drive, select "Get link," and then change the link settings to "Anyone with the link."

    \- You can then share this link without disclosing your email address.
2. Anonymous Access:

    \- If you use the shareable link method, users with the link can access the file without needing to log in or provide an email address, depending on the permissions you set.
3. Using a Different Account:

    \- If you want to keep your email completely private, you can create a new Google account specifically for sharing files. You can then share files from this account.
4. Third-party Services:

    \- Some third-party file-sharing services allow you to upload files and share them without revealing your email. However, be cautious with sensitive information when using third-party services.

Make sure to review the access settings to control who can view, comment, or edit the file.

content.text:
Based on my search, here are several alternative ways to access that Google Docs document:

## URL Modifications
If you have the document URL, try modifying it by replacing `/edit` with:
- `/preview` - Clean view without menus
- `/copy` - Forces you to make your own copy
- `/template/preview` - Shows preview with "Use Template" button
- `/export?format=pdf` - Downloads as PDF

## Anonymous Access
- Open the link in an **incognito/private browser window**
- This works if the document is set to "Anyone with the link can view"

## Request Access Changes
Ask the document owner to:
- Change sharing settings to "Anyone with the link can view"
- Share it as a different link type (template, copy, etc.)

## Browser Developer Tools
For certain file types, you can inspect the page source to find direct download links, though this requires technical knowledge.

## Alternative Sharing Methods
- Ask for the document to be shared via a different method
- Request a PDF export be sent directly
- See if it can be published to the web instead

The most reliable approaches are using incognito mode or asking the owner to modify the sharing permissions to "Anyone with the link."
The dotfiles folder location depends on your system and setup:

content.text:
Perfect! The symbolic link is working correctly. When you edit files in `/home/skamenan/dotfiles/claude/`, you're actually editing the files in `/home/skamenan/.claude/` directly through the symbolic link.

**No copying is needed** - any changes you make in the `dotfiles/claude` folder are automatically reflected in `~/.claude` because they point to the same location.

This is the beauty of symbolic links - they create a seamless connection between the two locations, so your dotfiles repo can track your Claude configuration while the actual config remains in the expected location.
